message.content: The theorem states that for any odd prime number $p$, if $a$ and $b$ are distinct natural numbers both less than $p$, then the sums $\sum_{i=0}^{p-2} (i + 1) a^i$ and $\sum_{i=0}^{p-2} (i + 1) b^i$ are not congruent modulo $p$.

The theorem states that for any odd prime number $p$, and any two distinct natural numbers $a$ and $b$ both less than $p$, the sums $\sum_{i = 0}^{p-2} (i + 1) a^i$ and $\sum_{i = 0}^{p-2} (i + 1) b^i$ are not congruent modulo $p$.

For any odd prime number $p$ and distinct natural numbers $a$ and $b$ that are both less than $p$, the sums $\sum_{i=0}^{p-2} (i + 1) \cdot a^i$ and $\sum_{i=0}^{p-2} (i + 1) \cdot b^i$ are not congruent modulo $p$.

The theorem states that for any odd prime number $p$, if $a$ and $b$ are distinct natural numbers less than $p$, then the sums $\sum_{i=0}^{p-2} (i + 1) a^i$ and $\sum_{i=0}^{p-2} (i + 1) b^i$ are not congruent modulo $p$.

For any odd prime number \( p \), and for any distinct natural numbers \( a \) and \( b \) both less than \( p \), the polynomial expressions \(\sum_{i=0}^{p-2} (i + 1) a^i\) and \(\sum_{i=0}^{p-2} (i + 1) b^i\) are not congruent modulo \( p \).
